title: Modifications to locked/symlink'd files not detected
body:
#### What is the problem?
Users may unknowingly modify a locked file by editing the contents of a symlink'd file and never receive any indication that they broke the dataset internals.
 
#### What steps will reproduce the problem?
Using an example from the [handbook](http://handbook.datalad.org/en/latest/basics/101-103-modify.html), if we jump in and create a fresh dataset w/o `text2git`
```
datalad create test-dataset
[INFO   ] Creating a new annex repo at /data/test-dataset
[INFO   ] Scanning for unlocked files (this may take some time)
create(ok): /data/test-dataset (dataset)
```
Then we create a text file
```
cat << EOT > notes.txt
One can create a new dataset with 'datalad create [--description] PATH'.
The dataset is created empty

EOT
```
And save it
```
datalad save -m "Add notes on datalad create"
add(ok): /data/test-dataset/notes.txt (file)
save(ok): /data/test-dataset (dataset)
action summary:
  add (ok: 1)
  save (ok: 1)
```
Now our user decides to edit the file in a text editor and when saving is presented with a "challenge" (e.g., in `vi` to use `:wq!` or in `atom` a dialog pops up to enter a password). Our user overrides and saves the content.

We can see the symlink'd file that was edited and that the md5 has changed
```
ll notes.txt
lrwxr-xr-x 1 nnichols wheel 120 Aug  3 16:40 notes.txt -> .git/annex/objects/4W/W2/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt

md5sum .git/annex/objects/4W/W2/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt
2e8a0c452def43ba11c127d63ce77314  .git/annex/objects/4W/W2/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt
```
However, both `git` and `datalad` are unaware of this change.

```
git status
On branch master
nothing to commit, working tree clean

datalad status
nothing to save, working tree clean
```

I see that `git annex fsck` will detect this and move the object to the "bad" place

```
git annex fsck
fsck notes.txt
  notes.txt: Bad file size (30 B smaller); moved to .git/annex/bad/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt

  ** No known copies exist of notes.txt
failed
(recording state in git...)
git-annex: fsck: 1 failed
```

I now see a symlink'd file that doesn't exist

```
ll notes.txt
lrwxr-xr-x 1 nnichols wheel 120 Aug  3 16:40 notes.txt -> .git/annex/objects/4W/W2/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt

cat notes.txt
cat: notes.txt: No such file or directory

cat .git/annex/objects/4W/W2/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt
cat: .git/annex/objects/4W/W2/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt/MD5E-s103--51afea194badf2dae12e76886cf2dfee.txt: No such file or directory
```

#### What version of DataLad are you using (run `datalad --version`)? On what operating system (consider running `datalad wtf`)?

```
datalad --version
datalad 0.13.1.dev118
```

#### Is there anything else that would be useful to know in this context?

This is primarily related to the user experience for working with and understanding locked/symlink'd files. If naively forces edits to files tracked by `git annex`, and they will, it would be a bit help to catch this somehow. 

Ideally this would enable the user to roll back their changes, but currently it appears that once a `git annex object` is trampled its history will be lost unless already backed up to another sibling.
